claim: You can't get enough protein on a vegan diet.
fact: A well-planned vegan diet provides all essential amino acids and adequate protein levels. Foods like legumes, tofu, seitan, and quinoa are excellent sources of plant-based protein. The average vegan easily meets or exceeds daily protein requirements.

citations.title: Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics: Position on vegetarian diets
Protein and amino acid contents in plant foods

fact: There's no scientific evidence that plants have nervous systems, pain receptors, or consciousness - all requirements for feeling pain. Plants respond to stimuli, but this is not the same as feeling pain or suffering.

citations.title: Plant consciousness: do plants feel pain?
Anesthetics and plants: no pain, no brain, and therefore no consciousness

fact: B12 supplements are recommended for vegans, just as they are for many people over 50 regardless of diet. Many foods are fortified with B12, and a properly planned vegan diet with supplementation provides adequate B12. Additionally, animals that omnivores eat are often fed B12 supplements.

citations.title: Vitamin B12 in the Vegan Diet
What every vegan should know about vitamin B12

claim: Veganism kills more animals through crop harvesting.
fact: Animal agriculture requires vastly more crops to feed livestock than would be needed to feed humans directly. A vegan diet actually requires less land and results in fewer total crop deaths than an omnivorous diet.

citations.title: The opportunity cost of animal based diets exceeds all food losses

claim: Veganism doesn't make a difference for the environment.
fact: Animal agriculture is a leading cause of greenhouse gas emissions, deforestation, water usage, and pollution. Research shows that plant-based diets can reduce your carbon footprint by up to 73%.

citations.title: Reducing food's environmental impacts through producers and consumers
